study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of implementing a progressive walking program early after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: Participants showed high adherence to activity monitoring and virtual sessions but met daily step goals only about half the time. No adverse events were reported, and qualitative themes identified factors promoting successful physical activity.
population_specificity: Ten individuals (60% female, mean age 20.2 ± 3.9 years, mean BMI 22.6 ± 2.9 kg/m²) within 8 weeks of unilateral ACLR.
effective_dosage: 12-week personalized progressive walking program with weekly virtual physical therapist visits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of combined vitamin E acetate and vitamin C treatments on infarct size and recovery of regional myocardial function in ischemic, reperfused porcine hearts.
results_summary: Therapy A (pre-ischemic vitamin E and pre-reperfusion vitamin C) significantly reduced infarct size and improved regional systolic shortening. Therapy B (intra-ischemic vitamin E and vitamin C) also reduced infarct size but to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: Ischemic, reperfused porcine hearts (30 thoracotomized pigs).
effective_dosage: Therapy A: vitamin E acetate (12 gm IV three times for 1 week) and vitamin C (4.4 gm IV); Therapy B: vitamin E acetate (12 gm intraarterially) and vitamin C (4.4 gm IV).
study_duration: 1 week for vitamin E in Therapy A; single doses for vitamin C in both therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between baseline vertical ground reaction forces during walking and worsening bone marrow lesions and cartilage damage in knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Higher peak impact forces during walking were associated with worsening bone marrow lesions and cartilage damage in specific knee regions, while higher average loading rates were linked to reduced odds of worsening in the lateral tibiofemoral joint.
population_specificity: Participants from the Multicenter Osteoarthritis Study (MOST) with baseline GRF data and MRI examinations at baseline and 2-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of task-specific walking training for a child with hereditary spastic paraplegia using orthoses and assistive mobility aids.
results_summary: The child improved walking ability, transitioning from knee-ankle-foot orthoses and a posterior walker to ankle-foot orthoses and crutches, with enhanced scores on functional mobility and motor measures.
population_specificity: A 4-year-8-month-old boy with hereditary spastic paraplegia, classified as Gross Motor Function Classification System level IV.
study_duration: Approximately 2 years and 3 months (from 4 years 8 months to 6 years 11 months)

study_goal: To investigate whether a home-based self-management program could promote physical activity more effectively than usual care in individuals with mild walking disability post-stroke.
results_summary: No statistically significant differences were found between groups at 3 and 6 months, but clinically meaningful improvements were observed in physical activity, self-efficacy, and participation at 3 months, and in self-efficacy and participation at 6 months.
population_specificity: Physically inactive individuals who had a stroke within the past six months and had mild walking disability (n=24).
effective_dosage: Experimental group received six 60-minute sessions over 3 months; control group received one 60-minute session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and initial impact of a digitally delivered mindful-walking intervention for improving the physical and psychosocial wellbeing of COVID-19 long haulers.
results_summary: Participants reported improved psychosocial moods (more positive affect, less negative affect), higher perceived cognitive ability, increased physical activity, and higher levels of momentary mindfulness. The intervention showed high acceptability and preliminary efficacy for mental wellbeing and physical activity.
population_specificity: COVID-19 long haulers (23 participants recruited via Facebook groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether semaglutide improves walking ability, symptoms, quality of life, and outcomes in people with peripheral artery disease and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Semaglutide significantly increased walking distance compared to placebo, with a median ratio to baseline of 1.21 vs. 1.08. Safety profiles were similar between groups, with few serious adverse events and no treatment-related deaths.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease (Fontaine stage IIa, able to walk >200 m).
effective_dosage: Subcutaneous semaglutide 1.0 mg once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a physical activity behavior change intervention (PABC) on sitting, standing, and stepping patterns, as well as free-living walking cadence, in Veterans recovering from unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The PABC group showed significantly more time spent walking at a brisk cadence compared to the control group, with the largest difference observed 24 weeks after the intervention ended. No differences were found in total sitting, standing, or stepping times or average bout durations between groups.
population_specificity: United States military Veterans recovering from unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if bilateral upper extremity blood flow restriction training (BFRT) during walking could safely and effectively improve strength and functional mobility in an adult with spina bifida who relies on crutches for ambulation.
results_summary: After 8 weeks of BFRT during walking, the patient showed significant improvements in walking speed (23%), mobility (20% faster TUG), sit-stand performance (22% faster), and upper extremity strength (8-79% gains), with no adverse events and high satisfaction.
population_specificity: A 29-year-old female with diastematomyelia (a rare form of spina bifida) and lower extremity weakness requiring crutches for walking.
effective_dosage: 4 bouts of walking per session, each lasting 3 minutes with 35-50% limb occlusion pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of once-a-week comprehensive physiotherapy combined with home exercise on musculoskeletal health in people with hemophilic arthropathy, focusing on joint health, functionality, and pain reduction.
results_summary: The study found that comprehensive physiotherapy once a week significantly improved joint health, functionality, balance, and pain reduction, while home exercise alone also showed improvements but to a lesser extent. Both groups experienced reduced hemarthrosis frequency.
population_specificity: Young people with hemophilic arthropathy (knee and/or ankle involvement).
effective_dosage: Comprehensive physiotherapy once a week (including manual therapy, neuromuscular electrical stimulation, and supervised exercises) plus home exercises two other days per week; home exercise group performed home exercises three days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a gait cycling protocol mimicking human walking to eccentric contraction protocols in mdx mice to better understand disease progression and treatment efficacy in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: The gait cycling protocol induced significant force loss in extensor digitorum longus (EDL) muscles but not soleus muscles, with effects comparable to eccentric contractions at 10% strain in soleus and 20% strain in EDL. The protocol was deemed valuable for studying DMD progression and evaluating new treatments.
population_specificity: Mdx mice (a model for Duchenne muscular dystrophy).
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocol involved up to 200 cycles of gait cycling and eccentric contractions at 10%, 20%, and 30% optimal length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of physical activity (measured via step counts) on cancer patients, categorizing them into active and inactive groups to assess differences in biometric and quality-of-life outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that the active walking group (AWG) showed significant improvements in waist circumference, visceral fat, and several quality-of-life aspects (energy, work, depression, memory, happiness) compared to the inactive group (IWG), though 6-month changes between groups were statistically insignificant.
population_specificity: Cancer patients who had previously used the Walkon app in a randomized controlled trial.
effective_dosage: Not specified (step counts were measured, but no prescribed dosage was mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of serial casting and exercise interventions on idiopathic toe walking (ITW) compared with a control group.
results_summary: No differences were found between the treatment groups in ankle ROM and TWSS at any follow-up points, but the control group showed less improvement in TWSS. Both intervention groups demonstrated significant intragroup improvements over time, with no significant differences between them.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic toe walking aged 3-10 years.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted posttreatment, 1-month posttreatment, 3 months posttreatment, and 6 months posttreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the underdiagnosis and unique risk factors of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in women, particularly focusing on diagnostic challenges and healthcare disparities.
results_summary: The study found that women with PAD often present with atypical or absent symptoms, leading to underdiagnosis and inadequate treatment, resulting in poorer outcomes. Early screening with the Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is crucial for accurate diagnosis and better management.
population_specificity: A 63-year-old woman with hypertension, chronic kidney disease, osteoporosis, and acute coronary syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a generative foundation model (GaitDynamics) to predict and analyze human gait dynamics for diverse clinical and performance applications.
results_summary: GaitDynamics accurately predicted ground reaction forces, knee loading changes from gait modifications, and kinematic/force changes with increasing running speeds, demonstrating potential for injury prevention, disease treatment, and performance coaching.
population_specificity: Diverse participant demographics and gait patterns

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study brain function characteristics in children with cerebral palsy (CP) during walking compared to healthy children (HC).
results_summary: Children with CP showed different brain activation patterns during walking, including increased prefrontal cortex (PFC) and motor cortex (MC) activation, altered functional connectivity, and difficulty maintaining stable global high-connectivity states compared to HC. These findings suggest CP affects brain resource allocation during walking.
population_specificity: 17 children with cerebral palsy (CP) and 13 healthy children (HC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining walking with respiratory training improves cardiopulmonary function and activity tolerance in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: The study found that walking combined with respiratory training significantly improved cardiac function (lower HR, LVEDD, LVESD; higher LVEF), pulmonary function (higher FVC, FEV1, FEV1/FVC), and activity tolerance (greater 6-min walking distance) compared to standard rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: 80 patients with CHF admitted to a cardiology department.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and optimal dose of walking interventions on specific cognitive domains (executive function, memory, attention, processing speed, and global cognition) in older adults.
results_summary: Walking interventions improved executive function (6 studies) and memory (3 studies), particularly when delivered individually, for at least 40 minutes per session, three times per week, over 6 to 26 weeks, and at moderate to vigorous intensity. Nine studies showed favorable effects on at least one cognitive domain.
population_specificity: Older adults without Alzheimer's or related dementias.
effective_dosage: At least 40 minutes per session, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the relationship between reduced walking speed, grip function, and cognitive decline in adults without dementia.
results_summary: The study found that decreases in walking speed and grip strength were significantly associated with cognitive decline, with the correlation becoming more pronounced when both factors were assessed jointly. Subgroup analysis indicated that study location, follow-up time, and cognitive assessment methods influenced the results.
population_specificity: Adults without dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine factors influencing walking ability after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and evaluate strategies to optimize post-operative recovery.
results_summary: The study found that walking ability after TKA is influenced by pre-operative factors, surgical techniques, and post-operative rehabilitation, with most patients experiencing significant improvements. Emerging technologies and biological augmentation techniques show promise for further enhancing recovery.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage knee osteoarthritis undergoing total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between walking (structured or free-living) and changes in brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) in locomotor-healthy humans.
results_summary: Walking at moderate to high intensities in single bouts was found to impact BDNF levels, though long-term effects remain unclear due to potential BDNF utilization for neuroplasticity or muscle repair. Age and environmental factors like heat also influenced BDNF increases.
population_specificity: Adult and older adult human subjects with healthy locomotion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of GTK® training on walking ability, GTK® riding performance, and health-related quality of life in children with walking disabilities.
results_summary: The study found a significant short-term improvement in functional walking ability (p = 0.009) but no long-term effect. GTK® riding performance improved significantly (p = 0.004), while health-related quality of life showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Children with walking disabilities (n=9).
effective_dosage: Twice a week for nine weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cognitive load affects stride-to-stride variability in walking patterns in individuals with and without functional ankle instability (FAI) using nonlinear evaluation tools.
results_summary: Individuals with FAI showed reduced variability in knee kinematics during walking with cognitive load, suggesting altered motor control strategies. Both FAI and healthy groups had longer reaction times during walking compared to sitting, indicating cognitive-motor interference.
population_specificity: 18 volunteers with functional ankle instability (FAI) and 19 healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Nordic Walking on quality of life and functionality in individuals with intellectual disabilities compared to another fitness intervention.
results_summary: The study anticipates providing insights into the effects of structured exercise interventions, but specific results are not yet reported in the abstract. Findings will be disseminated through peer-reviewed journals and conferences.
population_specificity: Individuals with intellectual disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online supervised training program involving walking (6MWT) in improving lipid and glucose metabolism in children with obesity and to assess its role as a predictor of metabolic improvement.
results_summary: The study found that the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) performance significantly improved after the intervention, correlating with reduced insulin levels, HOMA-IR Index, total cholesterol, and Atherogenic Index of Plasma (AIP), as well as improved health perception.
population_specificity: 35 Caucasian children with obesity, aged 8-13.
effective_dosage: Not specified (online supervised exercise training protocol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between early postoperative walking distance and clinical outcomes in patients who underwent lung cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study found a significant correlation between early postoperative walking distance and pre- and postoperative 6-min walk test performance, but no significant association with hospital stay length or complications. Early mobilization aligned with preoperative endurance levels, suggesting improved preoperative function may enhance recovery.
population_specificity: 104 patients who underwent lung cancer surgery between 2020 and 2023.
study_duration: Assessed within the first 24 hours after surgery and before discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare Timed Up and Go (TUG) test results with and without walking aids and their correlation with balance in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that using walking aids significantly improved TUG scores (42.32 sec with aids vs. 50.44 sec without aids, p=0.01) and showed high negative correlations with Berg Balance Scale scores, indicating better balance with aid use.
population_specificity: Twenty-five stroke patients (mean age 59.72 years, 17 male, 8 female) at least 2 months post-stroke, with Mini-Mental State Test >24 and ability to walk 10 meters with or without aids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence, timing, and risk factors of walking inability in pediatric patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) during early treatment.
results_summary: 15.0% of patients experienced walking inability at diagnosis, and 28.3% temporarily stopped walking during induction/consolidation. Younger age, decreasing weight, and longer hospitalizations were identified as significant risk factors.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (≤ 18 years) with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
study_duration: From diagnosis until the end of early treatment (specific duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week fitness walking programme could reduce metabolic syndrome risk factors and influence sex hormone levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The fitness walking programme significantly improved metabolic syndrome markers (reduced triglycerides, blood pressure, waist circumference, and fasting glucose; increased HDL-C) in postmenopausal women, while the control group showed worsening of these markers. A significant relationship between metabolic syndrome risk factors and sex hormone levels was also observed.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (aged ~60 years, BMI ~24 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, five times per week, at 50%-60% VO2max.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to survey caregivers about the use and perceived effectiveness of medical and behavioral treatments for toe walking in individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
results_summary: Caregivers reported that medical treatments like surgery were more commonly used and perceived as effective, while behavioral treatments were less known. Weighted boots were noted as an effective behavioral intervention, and most caregivers attributed toe walking to automatic positive reinforcement or underlying disorders.
population_specificity: Children with intellectual and developmental disabilities who engage in toe walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a treatment package (motor exercises, positive reinforcement, corrective feedback, and precision teaching) in reducing toe-walking in children with autism spectrum disorder.
results_summary: The study found a decrease in toe-walking across all participants, with improvements in gait patterns and physical mobility. However, limitations included a brief follow-up period and lack of generalization measurement.
population_specificity: Four male children with autism spectrum disorder, aged three to six years, with persistent toe-walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the 2-minute walk test (2MWT) could substitute the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) for assessing walking capacity in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) and to evaluate the validity of the 2MWT.
results_summary: The study found a very strong association between distances walked in the 2MWT and 6MWT, with higher gait speed during the shorter test. The 2MWT demonstrated robust convergent validity and the ability to discriminate between different disease severity levels.
population_specificity: 63 people with idiopathic, mild to moderate Parkinson's disease (29 women; mean age = 69.2 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking tests, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate spatio-temporal and sagittal plane kinematic differences between children with Idiopathic Toe Walking (ITW) and typically developing peers to identify biomechanical deficits.
results_summary: Children with ITW showed increased single support and swing phases, reduced walking velocity, and significant sagittal plane kinematic deviations, including reduced anterior pelvic tilt, hip and knee flexion, and excessive ankle plantarflexion. These findings suggest altered neuromuscular control and joint mechanics in ITW.
population_specificity: 30 children with ITW and 30 typically developing peers aged 6-12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the unexpected recovery of appetite in a spinal cord injury patient during exoskeleton-assisted walking therapy.
results_summary: A 30-year-old man with complete SCI (T8, AIS A) experienced appetite recovery after two sessions of exoskeleton-assisted walking, potentially linked to autonomic and visceral afferent improvements, though mood enhancement may also have contributed.
population_specificity: A single 30-year-old male with complete spinal cord injury (T8, AIS A).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Nordic walking compared to supervised exercise therapy in improving walking ability in patients with peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking ability (maximum walking distance and claudication distance) between supervised Nordic walking and supervised exercise therapy. However, supervised exercise therapy was significantly better at increasing exercise duration.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of psychosocial variables (commitment to walking and positive affect) on depression and activity acceptance in women with Fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study found that walking indirectly influenced activity acceptance through depression, with stronger effects observed in individuals with higher positive affect. Positive affect played a contextual role in mitigating depression's impact on activity acceptance.
population_specificity: 132 women with Fibromyalgia (FM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if machine learning-based methods could improve the sensitivity and specificity of analyzing coordination and balance in rodents using the beam walk task.
results_summary: The study successfully automated classical endpoint detection (e.g., foot slips) with high accuracy and used machine learning to identify 395 features, revealing pharmacological treatment effects and phenotypes in transgenic mice. The workflow, Forestwalk, provided deeper insights into balance control in health and disease.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice and transgenic mice used to study Angelman syndrome and SLC6A1-related neurodevelopmental disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate parental reports of toe walking frequency in children against quantitative in-shoe device measurements.
results_summary: The study found substantial agreement between parental reports and device measurements for combined forefoot and midfoot contacts (k=0.688) and fair agreement for isolated forefoot contact (k=0.381). Parental reports were relatively accurate, but quantitative devices provided more objective data.
population_specificity: Twenty children with persistent idiopathic toe walking (mean age 9.6 years, 13 males, 7 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dual-tasking (cognitive or motor tasks) reduces gait smoothness in Parkinson's disease patients during walking and turning.
results_summary: Dual-tasking decreased gait speed and increased step number in both straight-walking and turning. It also reduced gait smoothness, independent of speed and step number effects, particularly in the anterior-posterior direction during turning.
population_specificity: 33 Parkinson's disease patients (15 females; median age 71 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between depression and step count/walking capacity over two years in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Participants with depression showed a progressive decline in daily step count over 24 months, while those without depression maintained stable step counts. No significant difference in six-minute walking distance was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with walking impairment due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether blood flow-restricted exercise training (BFRET) improves lower extremity function and walking capacity recovery in post-stroke hemiparetic patients compared to standard exercise training (ET).
results_summary: BFRET showed superior improvements in muscle strength (hip flexion and plantar flexion) and lower extremity function compared to ET alone, suggesting it may enhance muscle hypertrophy and functional recovery.
population_specificity: Post-stroke hemiparetic patients (mean age 48.79 years, 75% male, mean time since stroke 2.5 years).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of training twice per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of wearable robot-assisted gait training (W-RAGT) versus treadmill gait training (TGT) in improving balance and walking ability in stroke patients.
results_summary: The W-RAGT group showed significant improvements in motor ability, balance, and walking metrics (cadence, step length, stride length) after 8 weeks, with sustained benefits at 16 weeks, outperforming the TGT group.
population_specificity: Sixty stroke patients (67.13 ± 11.36 years; 37 males, 23 females) from a hospital in Seoul, Korea.
effective_dosage: 30-minute training sessions, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 8 weeks of robotic exoskeleton-assisted gait training versus conventional gait therapy on walking adaptability and speed in individuals with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Individuals with MS who underwent robotic exoskeleton training showed improved walking adaptability (obstacle avoidance and augmented cues tracking) and increased average walking speed post-training compared to baseline, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Four female subjects (mean age 53 years) with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and ambulatory impairment.
effective_dosage: Sixteen 1-hour sessions (2 sessions per week for 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate muscle activation in the lower limbs during walking in elderly individuals with sarcopenia to identify potential rehabilitation strategies.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in muscle activation, particularly in the shank muscles (TA and GL), between sarcopenia patients and healthy elderly during walking, suggesting these differences may contribute to gait disorders. A strong correlation was observed between GL muscle activation and step length in sarcopenia patients.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with sarcopenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a peer-led, school-based walking intervention (WISH Study) in increasing physical activity levels among adolescent girls, using the RE-AIM Framework to assess participation, motivation, and enjoyment.
results_summary: The intervention showed mixed results, with 15% of pupils meeting physical activity guidelines at baseline, variable walk attendance (2-104 walks per school), and self-reported improvements in physical health, mental well-being, and social relationships. Implementation barriers included COVID-19, time constraints, and walk leader availability.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls (12-14 years) from 18 schools in Ireland and Northern Ireland.
effective_dosage: Brisk walks (10-15 min) during the school day, led by older peer walk leaders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multisystem exercises (including walking) versus conventional exercises on balance, postural stability, mobility, walking speed, and pain reduction in patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that multisystem exercises significantly improved balance, postural stability, mobility, and walking speed while reducing pain compared to conventional exercises, with statistically significant differences observed at both 4 and 8 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (n=50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and long-term benefits of Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) for improving walking difficulties in adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: FES showed a small, clinically insignificant initial effect on walking speed, but after three months of continuous use, the improvement became statistically and clinically significant (0.12 m/s difference). Long-term data (4 years) in a subset of patients confirmed sustained benefits (0.24 m/s difference), and patient-reported walking satisfaction improved.
population_specificity: Adults with cerebral palsy experiencing walking difficulties, including reported falls, foot drop, and tripping.
study_duration: 3 months for the main cohort, 4 years for a subset of 11 patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between walking-related physical therapy goal attainment and psychosocial factors in individuals with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Participants who met all walking-related PT goals had lower pain impact, fewer depression symptoms, and greater social support compared to those who did not meet their goals. The study suggests psychosocial factors may influence PT goal attainment in MS patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (N = 41) who engaged in physical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a highly sensitive electrochemical biosensor to detect DNA adenine methylation (Dam) MTase activity using DNA walker and rolled circular strand displacement amplification (RC-SDA) technology.
results_summary: The biosensor demonstrated excellent sensitivity and specificity in detecting Dam MTase activity, achieving a detection limit of 6.85 × 10-5 U/mL, and provided a basis for potential diagnostic and therapeutic applications in methylation-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of gamified versus pedometer-based walking interventions on physical activity, physical function, fatigue, sleep quality, and hemodynamics in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The gamified walking intervention significantly improved step count, fatigue, and sleep quality compared to the pedometer and control groups, but no significant differences were found in physical function or hemodynamics.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients at Mansoura University Hospital, Egypt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how to optimize ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) stiffness for individuals with plantarflexor weakness by assessing its effects on ankle moment and evaluating a method to predict optimal stiffness.
results_summary: The study found a quadratic relationship between AFO stiffness and net ankle moment, a positive linear relationship with AFO-generated moment, and a negative linear relationship with muscle-generated moment. The predicted optimal AFO stiffness based on peak ankle moment during shoes-only walking differed by 13.7% from the experimentally optimized stiffness.
population_specificity: 18 individuals with neuromuscular disorders and reduced ankle moments during shoes-only walking.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (AFO stiffness was experimentally optimized).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of an app-based intervention (NHS Active 10) combined with behavioral support calls and print materials to increase brisk walking in cancer patients.
results_summary: The intervention was successfully implemented, with high engagement rates (e.g., 95% downloaded the app, 83% used planners). Participants found the app, leaflet, and behavioral support calls useful, and the intervention showed promise for promoting habit formation and self-monitoring. Contextual factors like cancer treatment impacts and social support influenced engagement.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 y) with breast, prostate, or colorectal cancer who did not meet UK physical activity guidelines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of mindfulness scales (SMS, SMS-PA, and VAS-M) before, during, and after walking in a natural environment.
results_summary: The study found that the SMS and SMS-PA could be administered before, during, and after walking, with the SMS-PA showing concurrent validity with the SMS. However, the VAS-M did not meet concurrent validity criteria, and none of the scales demonstrated test-retest reliability.
population_specificity: Participants engaging in walking on a desert trail.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured after 10 minutes of walking; a subset repeated the intervention 24 hours later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose and evaluate the potential of Walking School as a sustainable movement-based education initiative to integrate physical activity into school culture.
results_summary: The study suggests that Walking School could be inclusive, extend classroom learning, reduce sedentary time, stimulate physical activity, and become part of the school's core educational culture.
population_specificity: Schools, including teachers and students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the use of multiple wearable sensors to detect Freezing of Gait (FoG) episodes in Parkinson's disease patients during various walking tasks under different medication conditions.
results_summary: The study is currently in the data collection phase, with preliminary recruitment of 3 patients as of August 2024. The accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity of wearable sensor combinations for detecting FoG episodes will be analyzed once data collection is complete.
population_specificity: 18 patients with Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involves walking tasks and medication conditions, not dosage).
study_duration: Data collection ongoing since February 2024, with results anticipated by end of 2025.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the physiological and cardiometabolic effects of a 12-week walking football program in physically inactive older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in grip strength, walking/turning speed (shorter Timed Up and Go test time), reduced waist circumference, increased HDL-cholesterol, and decreased HbA1c levels after the intervention.
population_specificity: Physically inactive older adults (mean age 74.0 ± 5.7 years, 11 men and 22 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences and perspectives of children with disabilities regarding outdoor play in French mainstream school playgrounds.
results_summary: The study identified environmental barriers to play, children's preferences for enriching play and inclusion, and the need for stronger participation in playground redesign.
population_specificity: Thirteen children with various disabilities across six mainstream schools in western France.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the functional outcomes of 1-month inspiratory muscle training (IMT) in elderly patients with intensive care unit acquired-weakness syndrome (ICUAWS) and severe walking disability.
results_summary: The study found that IMT significantly improved functional outcomes in ICUAWS patients, including walking performance (six-minute walk test, 10-m walk test), muscle strength, lung function, and quality of life measures compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with ICUAWS and severe walking disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a cognitively enriched walking program (WALK+) improved cognitive functioning and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) in older adults compared to a walking-only program (WALK-only) and a passive control condition (CONT).
results_summary: The study found no significant benefits of the WALK+ program on cognitive functioning compared to WALK-only or CONT. MVPA decreased in WALK+ over 12 months but increased in WALK-only and CONT at certain time points.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥65 years (median age: 69, 72% female).
effective_dosage: Two supervised group-based sessions per week (60-90 minutes/session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how aging-related deficits in muscle properties affect dynamic stability during walking.
results_summary: The study found that older adult models exhibited greater dynamic stability (higher MoS) than young adult models, with reduced maximum isometric muscle force being the most influential factor. These deficits limit control of dynamic stability during walking, suggesting potential fall risks in older adults.
population_specificity: Simulated musculoskeletal models representing young adults and older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the physiological and psychological effects of forest walking versus urban walking on healthy middle-aged to older men.
results_summary: Forest walking significantly increased saliva-secreted immunoglobulin A (sIgA) levels and improved mood, including reduced stress hormone levels, compared to urban walking.
population_specificity: Healthy men aged 40-70

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cilostazol, a treatment for peripheral artery disease, induces structural changes in red blood cells that correlate with improved walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that cilostazol caused significant structural changes in red blood cells, as indicated by shifts in thermal properties, which correlated with clinical improvements in walking distance. These findings suggest cilostazol enhances red blood cell function, contributing to better mobility in PAD patients.
population_specificity: 10 patients (5 men, 5 women) with peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining virtual walking therapy with a physical exercise program improves lower limb strength and muscle activation more effectively than physical exercise alone in people with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The experimental group (virtual walking + physical exercise) showed significant improvements in lower limb strength and muscle activation, maintaining gains up to one month post-intervention, while the control group (placebo virtual walking + physical exercise) only improved in hip abduction and extension. Virtual walking enhanced the effects of physical exercise on muscle strength and activation.
population_specificity: People with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI)
